claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.

combined_evidence.quote: Frequent development of antigenic variants through antigenic drift is the virologic basis for seasonal epidemics and the reason for the usual replacement of one or more influenza virus strains in each year's influenza vaccine.
combined_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote explains that influenza viruses frequently develop antigenic variants, which is a key reason for changes in vaccine composition each year. This supports the claim by establishing that mutations (antigenic drift) are a known issue in influenza virus biology, which can affect vaccine effectiveness.

combined_evidence.quote: Vaccine efficacy against antigenically matched culture confirmed CDC-ILI could not be determined reliably because 96% of the influenza isolates obtained from subjects in Study 1 were not antigenically matched to the strains represented in the vaccine.
combined_evidence.relevance_explanation: This quote demonstrates that the majority of influenza viruses isolated from vaccinated individuals were not antigenically matched to the vaccine strains, which supports the claim that mutations or changes during production (or circulation) can result in reduced vaccine effectiveness.
